awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Fire Influences on Forest Recovery and Associated Ecosystem Feedbacks in Arctic Larch Forests.

por.por_cntn:
Wildfire has shaped forests and even tundra of the Arctic region for much of the Holocene, but recent warming is intensifying fire activity. Fires are occurring more frequently and burning deeper into organic soils, releasing older carbon (C) to the atmosphere. Even regions that have rarely burned historically are vulnerable to crossing climate thresholds likely to increase fire activity. Because these forests and cold soils store approximately 30% of global terrestrial C in a pool twice the size of the atmospheric C pool, net C release from increased fire activity could push the Earth system over past thresholds that will fundamentally alter spatial and temporal climate dynamics during the remainder of the 21st century and beyond.

Forecasting whether and when future Arctic C release could initiate profound changes in global climate depends on how fire and ecosystem carbon balance responds to continued warming and drying over the next few decades. In this research, we explored fire impacts on key components of C cycling in boreal forests and the tundra-taiga ecotone underlain by C-rich permafrost soils.  Although this project initially focused on the larch forests and Yedoma permafrost soils of the Russian Far Northeast, pandemic travel restrictions and the outbreak of the Russian-Ukrainian War forced a transition in focus to the Northwest Territories (NWT) in Canada.

In Russia, this research revealed that burning reduced the soil organic layer, promoted deepening of the active layer, and initiated ground subsidence as permafrost thawed. By 20 years after fire, soils had lost almost half of the C stored in the upper 1.25 m depth increment. An even larger proportion of the growth-limiting nutrient nitrogen (N) was lost, suggesting that future forest regrowth and C sequestration may be diminished. In NWT, this research explored functional characteristics of legacy soils—residual soil organic matter that survived fire. Results showed that this material functions as a decay-resistant long-term C sink that also provides N to regrowing vegetation. Research on ecosystem N budgets showed that well drained, high productivity ecosystems lost a higher proportion of N pools during fire than poorly drained, low productivity ecosystems because of N allocation aboveground. High proportional losses of N during wildfire could reinforce nutrient limitation and decrease future carbon sequestration. 

The intellectual merit of this work arises from new insights into the rate and magnitude of wildfire impacts on soil C pools and forest C dynamics. Moreover, losses of N from fire could further diminish the potential for long-term C sequestration that balances permafrost C loss as the ecosystem recovers from disturbance. The broader impacts of this research arise from the training and mentorship of a PhD student and the career development of two early career women faculty. In the first two years of this project, work with Russian collaborators enriched research and training and travel to Russia improved US participants’ Russian language skills and reinforced cross-cultural communication.
